content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, I would consider the long-term strategy for this repeated game. Since both options (R and B) result in a positive payoff when chosen against the other option, there's no immediate dominance of one strategy over the other. However, when considering the sum of potential earnings over multiple rounds, it becomes clear that choosing B consistently could potentially be more beneficial due to the higher average payoff in case my opponent chooses R (35$ vs 0$).

However, if I assume that my anonymous opponent is also rational, they might think the same way and try to exploit me by choosing R whenever I choose B, getting a net gain of 35$ each time. To avoid this, I would need to mix up my choices between R and B to keep my opponent guessing.

In a lab experiment setting, it is likely that both players will have access to the strategies employed by their opponents, so they can adjust their own strategies accordingly. In such a scenario, neither strategy might be strictly optimal as both players would adapt to each other's choices over time.

Considering all these factors, I would still opt for B as my main strategy and occasionally switch to R to keep my opponent guessing. However, it is essential to recognize that the specific choice depends on assumptions about the behavior of my anonymous opponent. {B}

In this case, it's difficult to predict what their choice will be for the next round. However, since I don't want to give them an opportunity to exploit me by picking R when I choose B again (as I did earlier), I will continue with a mixed strategy myself.

In the next round, I could pick either R or B depending on my opponent's past choices and my current assumptions about their strategy. For example, if they have been consistently choosing B, I might switch to R in the next round to catch them off guard. Or, if I notice that they tend to switch between R and B more often, I could continue with a mixed strategy myself to keep the game unpredictable. {R (chosen as an example)}
